questions.question_text:
A user's mobile device is losing its battery charge very quickly. The user reports a 90% charge at 9:00 a.m., but has 22% battery by 1:00 p.m. The user has installed several applications, and the phone is a relatively new, high-end phone. The user claims most of the usage involves checking emails for a few minutes three or four times per hour.
Which of the following should a technician perform FIRST to diagnose the issue properly?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
TIP: Question were they asking about what should be done 'First', it is most of the time about 'checking/looking' things.

choices.A: Check the applications and their resource usage.
choices.C: Configure the email software to work on a fetch schedule instead of the push setting.
choices.B: Order a replacement battery and see if the phone maintains its charge.
choices.D: Wipe the phone entirely and reset all settings to their default states.
choices.F: Uninstall all the applications on the phone and see if the battery issues remain.

discussion.content:
Page-file is also known as Virtual Memory, now that is a term I know lol 
https://www.tomshardware.com/news/how-to-manage-virtual-memory-pagefile-windows-10,36929.html#:~:text=Pagefile%20in%20Windows%2010%20is%20a%20hidden%20system%20file%20with%20the%20.&text=Because%20the%20Pagefile%20works%20as,that%20your%20computer%20has%2C%20respectively.

Windows’ virtual memory starts by creating a page file that resides somewhere on your hard drive. The page file works like a temporary storage box. Windows removes running programs temporarily from RAM into the page file so other programs can load and run. If you have enough RAM to run all your programs, Windows does not need to use the page file—Windows brings the page file into play only when insufficient RAM is available to run all open programs.
- Mike Meyers e-book
"the paging file extends the RAM’s capacity, as it stores RAM data that has not been used or accessed lately" found on google search.
pageing from the RAM, drop the paging amount so the ram doesn't have to send information back to the hard drives and then back again for the cpu, slowing up the process
Why not Processor Scheduling?

comments.content: I'm assuming that tinkering around with the processor itself has a very high oopsie rate and doesn't give a warm and fuzzy on the risk/benefit analysis. A simpler solution would be to change (in this case increase) the page-file size to increase virtual RAM. It won't help performance (you're already dipping into virtual RAM), but it'll make the error messages go away.

discussion.content: Inventory management is based on asset tag or bar code. Changing the name of the computer wouldn’t affect inventory..

questions.question_text: Joe, a customer, requests to have a technician rename his laptop to the name of his favorite sports team. Which of the following documents MUST the technician consider before performing this action?

discussion.content:
"Inventory Management
Inventory management is the process of maintaining a database of which devices and systems exist within an organization. Inventory management is often done using a third-party program to keep track of devices within larger organizations." (uniontestprep)
I think you develop an acceptable use policy to prevent issues with inventory management, so I think B inventory management is the best answer.

Selected Answer: A
It's clearly A

AUP (Acceptable Use Policy)   Defines what actions employees may or may not perform on company equipment, including computers, phones, printers, and even the network itself. This policy defines the handling of passwords, e-mail, and many other issues.

Selected Answer: A
First of all, "Joe, a customer" is absolutely ambiguous. However, I take it he's an employee of a company. I don't see why the computer name would have to be updated on an inventory document. The company would have tracking labels on their computers, not reliant on the system name. I lean towards AUP for renaming a company computer. 
From Comptia:
There are many software suites and associated hardware solutions available for tracking and managing assets (or inventory). An asset management database can be configured to store as much or as little information as is deemed necessary, though typical data would be type, model, serial number, asset ID, location, user(s), value, and service information. Tangible assets can be identified using a barcode label or Radio Frequency ID (RFID) tag attached to the device (or more simply using an identification number).

An acceptable use policy (AUP) is a document that outlines a set of rules to be followed by users or customers of a set of computing resources, which could be a computer network, website or large computer system. An AUP clearly states what the user is and is not allowed to do with the these resources.

An AUP is very similar to the ubiquitous terms and conditions or end-user license agreements (EULA) found on almost all software applications. The main difference is that an AUP covers the use of a much larger shared computing resource, such as an LAN or website, as opposed to a single software item. One consequence of sharing is that an AUP typically goes into detail about etiquette and respect for fellow users of the resource, which is not applicable for single-user software applications.

Answers a

A. Acceptable use policy - a document stipulating constraints and practices that a user must agree to for access to a corporate network or the Internet. im just going out on a limb and assuming customer renaming his computer shows up on a network or internet.

Joe, a customer, requests to have a technician rename his laptop to the name of his favorite sports team. Which of the following documents MUST the technician consider before performing this action?

May its me who is not understanding the question, that is the important of the inventory to a customer PC, if joe was an employee at a company and calls a technician to rename his laptop, that could have been okay.

Im going to have to say renaming a laptop to a spots team is not going to interfere with inventory management. More or less would be a policy that would be broken that states computer names must remain the same.
Is there such thing as an inventory management document though?
AUP is the answer.

comments.content: I don't think so because changing the name could make it harder to track in inventory

AUP would imply the company has a specific rule regarding laptop names. If there is no such rule, then there would be no issue, except for possibly messing up the RMM/inventory management displays. If the senior admin says all PC names must follow "X-Y-Z" format then that's less about acceptable use and more about office procedure
